interesting_fact: This faint star (red dwarf) is known since at least 1886 but the first planet around it has been discovered only in 2005.
Its planetary system has three planets within its habitable zone. Any additional planet within the habitable zone would have destabilized the system.
This red dwarf hosts the fifth closest known planetary system (as of July 2018). Two of its planets are located in the habitable zone but they are believed to be similar to Jupiter (gas giants).
The system is considered an excellent target for studying atmospherics of exoplanets.
This is an orange (K-type) main-sequence star located in the constellation of Pictor. The star is surrounded by six known planets, three discovered in 2008 and three in 2012.

A team of European astronomers discovered that this star hosts three Neptune-mass planets using the HARPS spectrograph on ESO's 3.6-m telescope at La Silla (Chile). The star is also surrounded by an asteroid belt.
This system has been studied by the Keck telescope for over 10 years.
This star is surrounded by a debris disk and four planets. These planets were the first exoplanets whose orbital motion was confirmed via direct imaging.
This star is also known as EPIC 201367065 and can be found in the constellation Leo.
This system is an unusually flat compact solar system with lots of big planets orbiting close to the star. The closest 5 planets would all be closer than Mercury is to our Sun.
This is a binary star system (two bounded stars). Both stars are smaller than our Sun. The two stars complete an orbit around a common center of mass every 41 days.
Although the planets are not much bigger than the Earth they are not Earth like because they are much closer to their star than Earth and are hence not near the habitable zone.
This faint star (not visible with the naked eye) has a planet orbiting in its habitable zone. However this planet Kepler-27 c is a gaseous giant.
It is located in the constellation Lyra.

Kepler-56 is growing to become a red giant just like our Sun will. It is already 4 times larger than our Sun although it is only 1.3 times the mass. Some astronomers think there might be an extra planet further out in the system.
This system has 2 planets in the habitable zone. Kepler-62 is a K2 dwarf star 2/3rds size of the sun and 1/5th as bright. At 7 billion years, it is older than our Sun.
The star is only 1.3 times bigger than our Sun.
The first system showing multiple transiting planets. The star's properties are similar to our Sun. Planets c and b are affected by a 2:1 mean motion resonance.

This star is a pulsar - which means it is a compacting rotating star emitting a powerful beam of radiation. The exoplanets around this star were both the first extrasolar planets and the first pulsar planets to be discovered (1992-1994)

The ultracool dwarf star known as TRAPPIST-1 has 7 Earth-sized planets orbiting around it (discovered in 2016). Three of the planets lie in the habitable zone and could harbour oceans of water on their surfaces. This system has the largest number of known worlds that could support liquid water on their surfaces.
This giant gas-cloud planet WASP-12b is so close to its sun it is extremely hot (more than 2000 C) and is being pulled apart as it falls into the sun.
This system shows similarities to our own solar system. The orbits are nearly circular and co-planar and may have formed in the same way.
It is so close that it gives other opportunities to study to see if it has life. It hosts three super-earths.
YZ Cet is the 23rd closest star to our Sun but it is too faint to bee seen with the naked eye. This star shows occasional rapid and brief increases in brightness caused by eruptions from the surface.
This faint star (red dwarf) is known since at least 1886 but the first planet around it has been discovered only in 2005.
This star is spectrally similar to our Sun and it is the closest solitary such star (G-star) to our Sun.
